title: Complexity-aware worker pipeline
description:
Conductor gauges task complexity and adapts verification pipeline accordingly.

## Complexity Signals
- File count changed (1 file = simple, 3+ = complex)
- New files vs modifications
- LOC added/removed
- New exports/APIs introduced
- Touches existing tests?

## Pipeline by Complexity

| Change Type | Validation | Tests | Review |
|-------------|------------|-------|--------|
| Plugin/docs only | plugin-validator | skip | skip |
| Code (simple) | verify-build | run-tests | quick |
| Code (complex) | verify-build | run-tests + write-tests | thorough |

## Deliverables

### 1. Complexity Detection
Add to worker-done pipeline:
```bash
# After DOCS_ONLY detection
COMPLEXITY=$(detect_complexity)  # simple | complex
```

### 2. Test Writing Skill
New `/conductor:write-tests` skill:
- Analyze changed code
- Generate appropriate tests (unit, integration)
- Run after implementation, before commit
- Only for COMPLEXITY=complex

### 3. Code Review Auto-Select
Update `/conductor:code-review` invocation:
- COMPLEXITY=simple → quick mode
- COMPLEXITY=complex → thorough mode

## Existing Pattern
Already have DOCS_ONLY detection in worker-done.md that uses plugin-validator for markdown-only changes. Extend this pattern.

## Related
- TabzBeads-gok: user-invocable classification
- Existing: plugin-validator agent (plugin-dev:plugin-validator)

title: Add auto-detection guardrails to completion flow
description:
# Completion Guardrails

Auto-detect whether running as standalone (bd-work) or as spawned worker (bd-conduct).

## Detection Logic

```bash
is_worker_mode() {
  # Method 1: CONDUCTOR_SESSION env var (set by bd-conduct)
  [ -n "$CONDUCTOR_SESSION" ] && return 0
  
  # Method 2: Inside git worktree
  COMMON_DIR=$(git rev-parse --git-common-dir 2>/dev/null)
  GIT_DIR=$(git rev-parse --git-dir 2>/dev/null)
  [ "$COMMON_DIR" != "$GIT_DIR" ] && return 0
  
  return 1  # Standalone mode
}
```

## Behavior by Mode

**Standalone (bd-work):**
- Full pipeline: verify → tests → review → commit → close → push
- You control everything

**Worker (spawned by bd-conduct):**
- Limited pipeline: verify → tests → commit → close → notify
- NO push (conductor merges)
- NO code review (conductor reviews after merge)
- MUST notify conductor

## Guardrail Messages

Worker mode:
```
⚠️ WORKER MODE DETECTED
Skipping code review and push - conductor handles this.
```

Standalone mode:
```
✓ STANDALONE MODE
Running full pipeline with code review.
```

## Integration

- Used by /conductor:worker-done
- Used by bd-work completion
- Prevents workers from accidentally pushing

title: Add agent bead creation to worker spawn flow
description:
# Add Agent Bead Tracking to Worker Spawn Flow

Track spawned workers as agent beads using the beads agent system.

## Beads Agent API (actual commands)

### Create Agent Bead
```bash
bd create --type=agent --title="Worker: TabzBeads-abc" --labels="conductor:worker"
# Returns: TabzBeads-xyz (the agent bead ID)
```

### State Machine
```bash
bd agent state <agent-id> spawning  # Worker starting up
bd agent state <agent-id> running   # Worker executing
bd agent state <agent-id> working   # Worker actively on task
bd agent state <agent-id> done      # Worker completed
bd agent state <agent-id> stuck     # Worker needs help
```

### Attach Work to Agent
```bash
bd slot set <agent-id> hook <issue-id>  # Agent is working on this issue
bd slot clear <agent-id> hook           # Detach work when done
```

### Heartbeats (for monitoring)
```bash
bd agent heartbeat <agent-id>  # Update last_activity timestamp
```

### Query Agent State
```bash
bd agent show <agent-id>  # Show agent details
bd slot show <agent-id>   # Show what agent is working on
```

## Integration Points

1. **Worker spawn** (bd-swarm-auto):
   - Create agent bead with `bd create --type=agent`
   - Set state to `spawning`
   - Attach issue to hook slot: `bd slot set <agent> hook <issue>`
   - Set state to `running` when Claude initialized

2. **Worker heartbeat** (optional):
   - Periodic `bd agent heartbeat` calls
   - Enables Witness monitoring for stuck/dead detection

3. **Worker completion** (worker-done):
   - Set state to `done`
   - Clear hook slot: `bd slot clear <agent> hook`
   - Close agent bead or set to `idle` for reuse

## Files to Update

- plugins/conductor/skills/bd-swarm-auto/SKILL.md - Add agent creation to spawn flow
- plugins/conductor/skills/worker-done/SKILL.md - Add agent state updates to completion
- plugins/conductor/agents/conductor.md - Document agent bead usage
close_reason: Implemented agent bead tracking in spawn (bd-swarm-auto) and completion (worker-done) flows

title: Store prepared prompts in beads issue notes
description:
# Store Prepared Prompts in Beads Issue Notes

After backlog refinement (/conductor:bd-plan), issues should have pre-baked prompts stored in notes. Workers read the prompt from notes instead of exploring.

## Beads Notes API

```bash
# Store prepared prompt
bd update <issue-id> --notes "prepared.prompt: |
  Fix beads issue <id>: \"<title>\"
  
  ## Skills to Load
  - /ui-styling:ui-styling
  
  ## Context
  ...
  
  ## When Done
  Run: /conductor:worker-done <id>
prepared.skills: ui-styling,backend-development
prepared.files: src/components/Button.tsx,src/lib/utils.ts"

# Read notes
bd show <issue-id> --json | jq -r ".[0].notes"
```

## Schema (YAML in notes field)

```yaml
prepared.prompt: |
  Full worker prompt with all context
prepared.skills: skill1,skill2
prepared.files: file1.ts,file2.ts
prepared.completion: /conductor:worker-done <id>
```

## Integration

1. **bd-plan "Enhance Prompts"**:
   - Runs Haiku explorers to find files/skills
   - Stores results in issue notes via `bd update --notes`

2. **bd-swarm-auto spawn**:
   - Checks for `prepared.prompt` in notes
   - If present: uses verbatim (no exploration)
   - If absent: crafts prompt dynamically

- plugins/conductor/skills/bd-swarm-auto/SKILL.md - Read prepared.prompt from notes

title: Document user-invocable frontmatter pattern for skills
description:
Document the `user-invocable: false` frontmatter option for skills.

## Pattern
```yaml
---
name: internal-skill
description: Used by pipelines
user-invocable: false
---
```

## Conductor Skills Classification

### User-Invocable (bd-* = orchestration entry points):
- `bd-work` - spawn single worker
- `bd-swarm` / `bd-swarm-auto` - spawn parallel workers
- `bd-plan` (or `plan`) - backlog preparation
- `bd-status` - status overview

### User-Invocable (execution commands users call):
- `work` - you do the work yourself
- `worker-done` - signal completion (user or worker)
- `verify-build`, `run-tests`, `commit-changes`, `close-issue`, `code-review`

### Internal Only (user-invocable: false):
- `wave-done` - conductor only (post-merge)
- `create-followups` - pipeline step
- `update-docs` - pipeline step
- `worker-init` - worker self-optimization

## Naming Convention
- `bd-*` prefix = user orchestration commands (start/manage work)
- No prefix = execution commands (used during work)

2. Update meta:skill-creator references
3. Apply user-invocable: false to internal conductor skills

title: Unified Conductor Workflow v2
description:
# Unified Conductor Workflow v2

Phase 1 consolidation: merge bd-work, bd-swarm, bd-swarm-auto into unified commands with interactive prompts and guardrails.

See: docs/conductor-workflows.md section "PROPOSED: Unified Interactive Architecture" for full details.

## Design Decisions

### 1. Two Commands (refine + work)

Replace 4 entry points with 2 interactive commands:

```
/conductor:refine   →  Prepare issues (research phase, cheap Haiku via pmux)
/conductor:work     →  Execute issues (implementation phase, Opus workers)
```

### 2. /conductor:work AskUserQuestion Flow

```
/conductor:work
  Q1: "Here are the unblocked issues:" [multiSelect]
      → Select 1 = single worker mode (no worktree)
      → Select N = parallel workers mode (with worktrees)
  
  Q2: "How should this run?" [if N > 1]
      → Interactive = monitor, questions ok
      → Autonomous = waves until backlog empty
  
  Q3: "Worker count?" [if interactive + many issues]
      → 2, 3, 4, or "All ready issues"
```

### 3. /conductor:complete with Auto-Detection

Add guardrails to prevent workers from pushing/reviewing (conductor's job):

```
/conductor:complete <issue-id>
  Step 0: AUTO-DETECT MODE
    - CONDUCTOR_SESSION env var present → WORKER
    - Inside git worktree → WORKER
    - Otherwise → STANDALONE
  
  WORKER MODE:
    verify → tests → commit → close → notify
    ⚠️ DO NOT PUSH (conductor handles merge/review)
  
  STANDALONE MODE:
    verify → tests → code-review → commit → close → push prompt
```

Detection logic:
```bash
is_worker_mode() {
  [ -n "$CONDUCTOR_SESSION" ] && return 0  # Env var set by conductor
  COMMON_DIR=$(git rev-parse --git-common-dir 2>/dev/null)
  GIT_DIR=$(git rev-parse --git-dir 2>/dev/null)
  [ "$COMMON_DIR" != "$GIT_DIR" ] && return 0  # Inside worktree
  return 1
}
```

### 4. Deprecation Strategy

- `bd-work` → alias to `/conductor:work` + deprecation notice
- `bd-swarm` → alias to `/conductor:work` + deprecation notice  
- `bd-swarm-auto` → removed (use work with "Autonomous" selection)

## Blocked Issues

This epic blocks:
- TabzBeads-y4c: Implement /conductor:work skill
- TabzBeads-6jp: Implement /conductor:complete guardrails

## Acceptance Criteria

- [x] Design unified /conductor:work flow
- [x] Design auto-detection for worker vs standalone mode
- [x] Define deprecation strategy for old commands
- [ ] y4c implements /conductor:work
- [ ] 6jp implements /conductor:complete with guardrails
close_reason: Design complete. See issue description for unified workflow v2 design. Unblocks y4c and 6jp for implementation.

title: Replace custom monitoring with bd agent list
description:
# Replace Custom Monitoring with bd agent list

Remove custom monitor-workers.sh polling in favor of beads native agent tracking.

## Beads Agent Query API

```bash
# List all agent beads
bd list --type=agent

# List running agents (using label filter)
bd list --type=agent --label="state:running"

# Watch agents in real-time
bd list --type=agent --watch

# Show specific agent with state
bd agent show <agent-id>

# Show what agent is working on
bd slot show <agent-id>
```

## Replacement Strategy

**Current** (monitor-workers.sh):
- Polls tmux sessions with capture-pane
- Parses Claude output for status
- Manual, resource-intensive

**New** (beads native):
- Query `bd list --type=agent --label="conductor:worker"`
- Agent beads have state (running, done, stuck)
- Heartbeats enable automatic dead detection
- Built into beads, no custom scripts

## Files to Update

- Remove: plugins/conductor/scripts/monitor-workers.sh
- Update: plugins/conductor/skills/bd-swarm-auto/SKILL.md - Use bd list for monitoring
- Update: plugins/conductor/agents/conductor.md - Document new monitoring approach

title: Update bd-swarm/bd-swarm-auto to use prepared prompts with Haiku fallback
description:
When spawning workers, check for `prepared.prompt` in issue notes:

## Happy Path (prompt exists)
```
bd show <id> --json | jq -r '.[0].notes'
→ Has prepared.prompt? Use it directly, skip exploration
```

## Fallback Path (no prepared prompt)
If `prepared.prompt` not found:
1. Spawn Haiku agent in forked session (cheap exploration)
2. Agent runs skill to craft prompt:
   - Match skills (`match-skills.sh --verify`)
   - Find key files (Task(Explore) with haiku)
   - Store result in `prepared.prompt`
3. Then spawn the actual worker with the crafted prompt

## Implementation
```bash
# Check for prepared prompt
NOTES=$(bd show "$ISSUE_ID" --json | jq -r '.[0].notes // ""')
PREPARED_PROMPT=$(echo "$NOTES" | grep -A1000 'prepared.prompt:' | sed '1d')

if [ -n "$PREPARED_PROMPT" ]; then
  # Use prepared prompt directly
  WORKER_PROMPT="$PREPARED_PROMPT"
else
  # Spawn Haiku to craft prompt first
  Task(
    subagent_type="prompt-enhancer",
    model="haiku",
    prompt="Craft a worker prompt for issue $ISSUE_ID..."
  )
  # Then read the newly stored prepared.prompt
fi
```

## Benefits
- Pre-planned work: instant worker spawn (no exploration delay)
- Unplanned work: still works, just uses cheap Haiku first
- Conductor stays simple - just reads prompts and spawns

## Applies To
- `/conductor:bd-work`
- `/conductor:bd-swarm`
- `/conductor:bd-swarm-auto`
close_reason: Superseded by TabzBeads-32q (complexity-aware pipeline). Current conductor already sends accurate skill-aware prompts - don't need prepared prompts optimization.

title: Create /conductor:bd-work skill (standard single-session workflow)
description:
# bd-work - Standard Single-Session Workflow

YOU do the work. No spawning, no orchestration.

## Flow

```
/conductor:bd-work [issue-id]
  │
  ├── If no ID: AskUserQuestion "Here are the unblocked issues:"
  ├── Claim issue: bd update <id> --status=in_progress
  ├── Follow PRIME.md workflow
  │   ├── Implement the fix/feature
  │   ├── verify-build
  │   ├── run-tests
  │   ├── code-review (you decide)
  │   ├── commit-changes
  │   └── close-issue
  └── Push: bd sync && git push
```

## Key Points

- **No spawning** - You ARE the worker
- **Standard beads flow** - Follow PRIME.md
- **Full control** - You decide on review, tests, etc.
- **Single session** - No conductor, no workers

## When to Use

- Working on one issue at a time
- Don't need parallel workers
- Want full control over the workflow
close_reason: Created /conductor:work skill with single-session workflow

title: Create frontend plugin with progressive disclosure skills
description:
# Create Frontend Plugin (LOCAL)

Create at `./my-plugins/plugins/frontend/frontend-core/` (local copy).

NOTE: frontend-development and ui-styling already exist! Check if we need a new plugin or just update existing ones.

## Existing Plugins in my-plugins/plugins/frontend/
- aesthetic/
- frontend-design/
- frontend-development/ (already has SKILL.md)
- ui-styling/ (already has SKILL.md)
- web-frameworks/

## Decision
Review existing plugins first. May just need:
1. Update marketplace.json description
2. Add progressive disclosure to existing agent (if any)

## If New Plugin Needed
```
my-plugins/plugins/frontend/frontend-core/
├── plugin.json
├── agents/
│   └── frontend-expert.md       # Progressive disclosure agent
└── skills/
    ├── react/SKILL.md
    └── accessibility/SKILL.md
```
close_reason: Created frontend-expert agent with progressive disclosure pattern. Agent knows general patterns and invokes specific skills (frontend-development, ui-styling, aesthetic, web-frameworks) as needed.

title: Create code-review plugin
description:
# Create Code Review Plugin (LOCAL)

Create at `./my-plugins/plugins/tools/code-review/` (local copy).

## Structure
```
my-plugins/plugins/tools/code-review/
├── plugin.json
├── agents/
│   └── reviewer.md              # Code review expert
└── skills/
    ├── review/SKILL.md          # Standard code review
    ├── silent-failures/SKILL.md # Error handling audit
    └── security/SKILL.md        # Security-focused review
```

## Source Files (to migrate)
- plugins/conductor/agents/code-reviewer.md
- plugins/conductor/agents/silent-failure-hunter.md

## Plugin.json Template
```json
{
  "name": "code-review",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "Code review practices with confidence-based filtering",
  "skills": ["skills/review", "skills/silent-failures", "skills/security"],
  "agents": ["agents/reviewer.md"]
}
```
close_reason: feat(code-review): create standalone code-review plugin with agents and skills - migrated from conductor
